questions.text: A child has got a congenital cataract involving the visual axis which was detected by the parents right at birth, This child should be operated on:

options.label: A
options.text: Immediately

options.label: B
options.text: At 2 months of age

options.label: C
options.text: At 1 year of age when the globe becomes normal size

options.label: D
options.text: After 4 years when entire ocular and orbital growth becomes normal

questions.explanation:
Solution:

Immediately Congenital cataract refers to lens opacity presents at birth , developing either during 1st 2 years of life, infantile or later, developmental cataract Types: Zonular / lamellar cataract Punctate cataract Anterior pole cataract Posterior pole cataract Punctate cataract Coronary cataract Rx Based on the density it treated, if U/L is dense urgent surgery to reduce the risk of amblyopia If B/L dense cataract , early surgery within 4- 6 weeks of life

Highyeild:

Indications for surgery in the pediatric group Dense cataract > 3mm in diameter, covering the visual axis The pupil doesn’t dilate Squint/ nystagmus is seen to develop Lens aspiration with anterior vitrectomy with posterior capsulorhexis and IOL implantation Extracapsular cataract extraction techniques are the choice

Extraedge:

Under correction If < 2yr by 20% of under-correction 2-8 yr by 10% > 8 yr full correction

questions.text: A patient presented with diminished vision and neuropsychiatric manifestations and with hepatic dysfunction. His eyes on the general examination and slit lamp examination appeared as shown in the Figure below. What investigation you will do next

options.label: A
options.text: Serum Ceruloplasmin Level

options.label: B
options.text: 24 hr Urine copper level

options.label: C
options.text: MRI brain

options.label: D
options.text: Haplotyping

questions.explanation:
Solution:

Serum Ceruloplasmin Level The image represents the "Kayser-Fleischer '' ring - the KF ring is a golden brown ring due to the deposition of copper in Descement's membrane of the cornea.

Highyeild:

Wilson's Disease : Rare autosomal recessive disease.Characterized by abnormal copper metabolism Sternlieb's criteria : Presence of KF rings.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options: - Option: B . Decreased serum ceruloplasmin (copper-containing enzyme/ ferroxidase) levels. Measuring hepatic copper levels in liver biopsy 24-Hr urine copper excretion Kayser Fleischer ring: Excess circulating copper deposits in descemet's membrane. Options: C and D . Usually, golden brown is located in the peripheral cornea, beginning at Schwalbe's line up to 5 mm into the cornea. Detected via Gonioscopy in earlier stage & seen by naked eyes in advanced stage

questions.text: Identify the pathology depicted in the given Image

options.label: A
options.text: Blue Dot Cataract

options.label: B
options.text: Hypopyon

options.label: C
options.text: Seclusio pupillage

options.label: D
options.text: Posterior subcapsular cataract

questions.explanation:
Solution:

Blue Dot Cataract Congenital cataract refers to lens opacity presents at birth, developing either during 1st 2 years of life, infantile or later, developmental cataract Types : Zonular / lamellar cataract Punctate cataract Anterior pole cataract Posterior pole cataract Punctate cataract Coronary cataract

Highyeild:

Rx Based on the density it treated, if U/L is dense urgent surgery to reduce the risk of amblyopia If B/L dense cataract, early surgery within 4- 6 weeks of life Indications for surgery in the pediatric group Dense cataract > 3mm in diameter, covering the visual axis The pupil doesn’t dilate Squint/ nystagmus is seen to develop Lens aspiration with anterior vitrectomy with posterior capsulorhexis and IOL implantation Extracapsular cataract extraction techniques are the choice

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options: - Option: B. Hypopyon - Hypopyon—a layering of white blood cells in the anterior chamber—signifies severe anterior segment intraocular inflammation. The frequency of hypopyon has been described in two small to moderate-sized series of patients with various types of uveitis. Option: C. Seclusio pupillage - Seclusio pupillae occurs when the synechiae extend 360 degrees around the pupillary border. Peripheral anterior synechiae may lead to secondary angle-closure glaucoma if they fuse circumferentially and are typically found inferiorly. PAS is more often found superior when associated with primary angle closure. Option: D. Posterior subcapsular cataract - A posterior subcapsular cataract starts as a small, opaque area that usually forms near the back of the lens, right in the path of light. A posterior subcapsular cataract often interferes with your reading vision, reduces your vision in bright light, and causes glare or halos around lights at night.

Extraedge:

Under correction If < 2yr by 20% of under-correction 2-8 yr. by 10% > 8 yr. full correction

questions.text: A patient admitted to the medicine ward was referred to the ophthalmology department. He had features like frontal baldness and temporal bossing. He also has a history of heart conduction defects. After proper investigations, the given image was a key finding in the person. What is the finding seen in the image and the condition associated with the vignette?

options.label: A
options.text: Sunflower Cataract - Wilson's disease

options.label: B
options.text: Christmas Tree Cataract - Myotonic Dystrophy

options.label: C
options.text: Snowflake Cataract - Diabetic Mellitus

options.label: D
options.text: Rosette Cataract- Blunt Trauma

questions.correct_answer: B. Christmas Tree Cataract - Myotonic Dystrophy
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Christmas Tree Cataract - Myotonic Dystrophy The given features of the patient lead to a diagnosis of Myotonic Dystrophy and the image shown is Christmas Tree Cataract which is a characteristic finding of Myotonic Dystrophy.

Highyeild:

Oil droplet Cataract- Galactosemia Snowflake Cataract - Diabetes Mellitus Christmas Tree Cataract- Myotonic Dystrophy Sunflower Cataract- Wilson's disease Here are some of the images of the named Cataracts Christmas Tree Cataract

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options: - Option:A. Wilson's disease specifies features like neurological abnormalities, Keyser Fleischer rings and a low ceruloplasmin level Sunflower Cataract-Wilson's disease Option:C. The patient is not mentioned to be a Diabetic. Hence a diagnosis of Diabetes Mellitus is not appropriate. Snowflake Cataract - Diabetes Mellitus Option:D. There is no history of a Blunt Trauma mentioned. Hence not an appropriate diagnosis. Rosette Cataract -Blunt Trauma

questions.text: Given below are a set of specific named Cataracts and another set of conditions that are likely to cause cataracts. Oil Droplet Cataract Snowflake Cataract Christmas Tree Cataract Sunflower Cataract Diabetes Mellitus Wilson's disease Galactosemia Dystrophia Myotonica Which of the following correctly matches the above-named Cataracts with the conditions they are associated with?

options.label: A
options.text: I - c, II - a, III - d, IV - b

options.label: B
options.text: I - c, II - b, III - a, IV - d

options.label: C
options.text: I - d, II - c, III - b, IV - a

options.label: D
options.text: I - a, II - b, III - c, IV – d

questions.correct_answer: A. I - c, II - a, III - d, IV - b
questions.explanation:
Solution:

I - c, II - a, III - d, IV - b Oil droplet Cataract- Galactosemia Snowflake Cataract - Diabetes Mellitus Christmas Tree Cataract- Myotonic Dystrophy Sunflower Cataract- Wilson's disease Here are some of the images of the named Cataracts Rosette Cataract-Blunt Trauma Shield Cataract - Atopic Dermatitis Christmas Tree Cataract- Myotonic Dystrophy Sunflower Cataract-Wilson's disease Snowflake Cataract - Diabetes Mellitus

questions.text: A 50-year-old male patient who is a known Diabetic for several years has come to Ophthalmology OPD with complaints of blurring of vision. The doctor suspects it to be a Cataract associated with diabetes. Which of the following statements about the Cataract is NOT TRUE?

options.label: A
options.text: It is a Presenile Diabetic Cataract that starts to develop a few years earlier than a non Diabetic

options.label: B
options.text: It is more common than TRUE Diabetic Cataract

options.label: C
options.text: Snowflake Cataract is purely seen in Presenile Cataract and not True Diabetic Cataract

options.label: D
options.text: Cataract sets in early because of increased oxidative damage and crystallin glycation

questions.correct_answer: C. Snowflake Cataract is purely seen in Presenile Cataract and not True Diabetic Cataract
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Snowflake Cataract is purely seen in Presenile Cataract and not True Diabetic Cataract Snowflake Cataract is a key feature of True Diabetic Cataract (not Presenile Diabetic Cataract)

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options: - Option:A. The long-standing Diabetic patient is suffering from Presenile Diabetic Cataract . It usually sets in 10 to 15 years earlier when compared to a non Diabetic person. Its progression is dependent on the Diabetes duration. Option:B. True Diabetic Cataract is a rare condition that occurs in a younger age group who suffers from acute diabetes. The early stages of this cataract are reversible. Option:D. The reason for cataracts to set in early in Diabetic patients is because of increased oxidative damage and carbamylation & glycation of the crystallins.

questions.text: Nutritional abnormalities in the lens which usually occur due to degenerative or inflammatory diseases of the eye other than the lens also cause cataracts. Here are a few statements about this variant of Cataract. I. This Cataract is called a Complicated Cataract II. Chronic Anterior Uveitis Is a common cause of it III. Polychromatic Lustre is a key feature of this cataract IV. Posterior subcapsular Cataract is observed in it Which of the following statements about the above-given vignette is TRUE?

options.label: A
options.text: I, II, and III are true

options.label: B
options.text: I, II, and IV are true

options.label: C
options.text: II, III, and IV are true

options.label: D
options.text: I, II, III, and IV are true

questions.correct_answer: D. I, II, III, and IV are true
questions.explanation:
Solution:

I, II, III, and IV are true All the above-given statements are true. Option I: Complicated Cataract is a type of Cataract that results due to nutritional abnormalities in the lens which usually occurs due to degenerative or inflammatory diseases of the eye other than the lens. Some of the conditions causing it include - Option II Chronic Anterior Uveitis/Iridocyclitis Ciliary Body Tumours Retinitis Pigmentosa Retinal Detachment Degenerative Myopia Gyrate Atrophy Option IV There is a characteristic opacity that begins to set in the Cortex in its posterior part which leads to Posterior Subcapsular Cataract.

Highyeild:

Key Clinical Features of complicated Cataracts are Breadcrumb Appearance Polychromatic Lustre (rainbow-like display)

questions.text: A patient who is undergoing radiation therapy for a salivary Gland malignancy comes to the OPD with complaints of blurring of vision. He says something is blocking his view. After proper examination, the Ophthalmologist suspects it to be Irradiation Cataract. Which of the following statements given below about Irradiation Cataract is NOT TRUE?

options.label: A
options.text: It is caused mainly by ionizing radiation rather than non-ionizing radiation

options.label: B
options.text: Infrared Radiation causes Glass Blowers Cataract

options.label: C
options.text: MRI exposure has a risk of Cataract formation

options.label: D
options.text: The changes start near the equator soon after radiation.

questions.correct_answer: C. MRI exposure has a risk of Cataract formation
questions.explanation:
Solution:

MRI exposure has a risk of Cataract formation MRI exposure has no risk for Irradiation Cataracts. Radiation exposure due to radiotherapy for malignancies near the eye (usually head and neck cancers) causes Irradiation Cataracts. It is mainly caused due to ionizing radiations like Gamma rays, X-rays, or neutrons.

Highyeild:

MRI never uses ionizing radiation; it is not a risk factor for cataracts.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options: - Option: B. Infrared radiations are mainly from the constant heat radiations in Glass producing industries. Hence it is a risk factor for the Glassblowers Option: D. The changes in the lens are due to the radiations acting directly on the dividing fibers in the lens. The changes begin from the equator soon after the radiation exposure. Maturation of this type of Cataract is rapid.
